Award.AwardTitle: CC*IIE Campus Design: Building a Next-Generation Research Network for Vassar College

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project provides a Science Research Network utilizing next-generation technologies to dramatically reduce and remove barriers to the free flow of scientific research data at Vassar College. The enhanced network better supports the transfer of large data sets with dramatically increased network capacity and reduced latency, positioning science researchers to utilize distributed data collection, remote sensor networks and pursue other network-enhanced research.

This project upgrades the current network core to a fully meshed 10Gbps backbone to facilitate high-capacity science research data transmission across the Vassar network. A dedicated science research network, a Science DMZ, is designed and implemented to enable the unfettered flow of science data across and between researchers, data collection, analysis and storage resources. Researchers are provided direct access from the Science DMZ to Research and Education (R&E) Networks including the New York State Education & Research Network and Internet2, with access to distributed computing resources including the New York State High Performance Computing Consortium (HPC2), as well as the commodity Internet in support of scientific research. Additionally fiber connections to the local Point of Presence (POP) are reconfigured to enable dramatically greater network throughput.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant effort significantly expanded the range of options available for Vassar researchers, particularly for those with computationally intensive needs. The opening of the Bridge for Laboratory Sciences and the larger Integrated Science Commons facilities on campus in early 2016 significantly expanded these opportunities.

As one example, Vassar’s original NSF proposal cited the work of Associate Professor of Economics Benjamin Ho, who was working with a data set of 72 million files to study habit formation in homeowners’ thermostat usage. After successfully negotiating access to these proprietary data, Dr. Ho spent weeks downloading the files and then faced the challenge of transferring these data to and from High Performance Computing (HPC) resources on campus. As a result of these efforts his transfer speeds increased by 50% and he was able to download the files in under one hour. As a result of these improvements and the removal of a significant obstacle to his research, Dr. Ho is looking to further expand his research agenda, including a possible collaboration using machine learning and predictive analytics.

Dr. David Esteban, Associate Professor of Biology has benefitted from the Science DMZ resources. The group of software packages and scripts Dr. Esteban uses in his research analysis is configured to run on parallel computing systems due to the significant computational demands of the grouping process. The High-Performance Computing resources historically available at Vassar could no longer meet Dr. Esteban’s computational needs. Using the Science DMZ and other project enhancements a scalable solution was built on Amazon Web Services (AWS) that mirrored and expanded on his on-campus environment. In order to accomplish this, a connection to Dr. Esteban’s on-campus HPC user space was routed through the Science DMZ directly to an AWS instance over the campus Internet2 connection with a low latency SSH connection. The frictionless nature of the Science DMZ dramatically enhanced the encrypted transfer.

As an example of how these uses can extend beyond the sciences, Dr. Andrew Tallon in Art History is collaborating on his 5 billion laser scan data points of Canterbury Cathedral with his Research Assistant, who is currently in Scotland, and colleagues at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Due to the high-speed network connection, he is able to do this research without Vassar’s having to invest in on-campus computing hardware that would be expensive to acquire, would be difficult to utilize to its full capacity and would become rapidly outdated with time. Additional information about Dr. Tallon’s work is available at http://gothicstucture.org.

Science DMZ connections were established in additional locations, including the following research uses, unfortunately, these efforts were still underway and had not yielded full outcomes at the time of this report.  

  • in the Skinner Hall of Music to be used for high-quality, low-latency music transmissions, for guest artists, master classes, auditions, and real-time, multi-location performances via the LOLA protocol.

  • in the Bridge for Laboratory Sciences building, in support of Dr. Teresa Garrett’s research. An Associate Professor of Chemistry, Dr. Garrett collaborates with data sets between Vassar and Scripps Research Institute in San Diego and will be exploring how the new connection can help her.

  • in the historical Vassar Observatory building and the Astronomy lab in the Sanders Physics building to facilitate the transfer of imagery and other large data sets from the telescope to workstations in the astronomy lab.

  • in the Sanders Physics building for Computer Scientist Dr. Marc Smith whose research areas include parallel computing and phyolgenetic classification (bioinformatics). He expects to be able to take advantage of the new connection and is exploring its potential.

  • in the Sanders Physics building for Computer Science researcher Dr. Nancy Ide. Dr. Ide’s Language Applications Grid (LAPPS), a collaborative project involving Vassar (NSF award no. 1147944), Brandeis, Carnegie Mellon, and the Linguistic Data Consortium at the University of Pennsylvania is poised to take advantage of the Science DMZ in support of their collaborative efforts as network capacity and often been a limiting factor, and users typically want to use the largest data set they can. Additionally, Dr. Ide and her team received an XSEDE allocation in 2016 in support of these efforts.

  • at the Collins Field Station, a site on The Vassar Farm, a 525 acre ecological preserve. Built in 1995, the field station is used to study natural history, ecology, botany, and geology and contains a library, classroom, laboratory, computers, and a modern weather station. The faculty and staff of the field station hope to use high-quality, low-latency videoconferencing technology to bring remote scientists into educational events, and are now envisioning opportunities to extend research opportunities through the Science DMZ resources.
